subject: Re: [junit] Need help!!
msgSnippet: ... From: Morten Grum, PH-Consult  ... code ... As others have pointed out, that is *not* the unit test approach. They pointed out that they and
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "Morten Grum, PH-Consult" <mg@...>
>
> The Unit test approach is "write the test before the code". So, if your
code
> is done then yes it's too late. Then there isn't any unit test approach.
> Just stick to use-case tests.

As others have pointed out, that is *not* the unit test approach. They
pointed out that they and others have written unit tests for legacy code,
and that it is never too late to write such tests. I would point out that
there is (at least in my mind) a difference between Test Driven Development
and Unit Testing; Unit Testing is a tool that TDD uses to accomplish its
goals and objectives, but Unit Testing can be used in various other ways and
at various other times. As I have said here recently, I advocate Unit
Testing by independent testers *after* code has been written - even when TDD
was used in the design and development of that code. While TDD may be the
first time code is tested, it is not the only or last time that code code
needs to tested - it is just the earliest time.

FWIW,
Lauren
